Introduction

If you are just wanting to play the game, please look here for the mac binary install: Note to self, create mac binary install :)
If you are wanting to build Peragro Tempus from scratch so you can play with the code, then this guide is for you! :)

Install Xcode

Download and install Xcode from Apple. This is obtained for free from here., but requires a registration. After you have registered and logged in, it is located under Downloads, and then Development tools. You need this to get a compiler installed on your machine. Unfortunately, the download is huge (950MB), and contains a lot that you most likely never will use. Xcode also comes with an up to date version of cvs which it installs for you. This might not be useful anymore however since PS has switched to svn. Install fink It is downloaded from here. Note: Do not use darwinports if you are using fink. It can cause conflicts if they both have the same package installed. Open a terminal window and set the required environment variables for fink by issuing the following command: 

# /sw/bin/pathsetup.sh
# source /sw/bin/init.sh

Configure fink (Optional) We are going to configure fink to download and install packages from source only. (no binary packages) This step is optional, but has a better success rate for installing the fink dependencies. 

# fink configure

Provided below are the questions and the standard recommended answers for the configuration: Password: OK, I'll ask you some questions and update the configuration file in '/sw/etc/fink.conf'. In what additional directory should Fink look for downloaded tarballs? [] Which directory should Fink use to build packages? (If you don't know what this means, it is safe to leave it at its default.) []

Should Fink try to download pre-compiled packages from the binary distribution if available? [y/N] n (1) Quiet (do not show download statistics) (2) Low (do not show tarballs being expanded) (3) Medium (will show almost everything) (4) High (will show everything)

How verbose should Fink be? [4] 4

Proxy/Firewall settings Enter the URL of the HTTP proxy to use, or 'none' for no proxy. The URL should start with http:// and may contain username, password, and/or port specifications. Note that this value will be visible to all users on your computer. Example, http://username:password@hostname:port Your proxy: [none] Enter the URL of the FTP proxy to use, or 'none' for no proxy. The URL should start with http:// and may contain username, password, and/or port specifications. Note that this value will be visible to all users on your computer. Example, http://username:password@hostname:port Your proxy: [none] Use passive mode FTP transfers (to get through a firewall)? [Y/n] y

Mirror selection All mirrors are set. Do you want to change them? [y/N] n

Writing updated configuration to '/sw/etc/fink.conf'...

Install ftjam

Download ftjam from here (Alternatively, search for ftjam on google. You should download the source code (I got ftjam-2.5.2.tar.gz) If you unpack it on the desktop, issue the following commands in the terminal window: 

# cd Desktop/ftjam-2.5.2
# ./configure --prefix=/sw/
# make
# sudo make install

Once that is completed, we can now fetch all packages that are needed using the following command: 

 fink -y -v install libjpeg freetype freetype-shlibs freetype2 freetype2-dev freetype2-shlibs libogg libvorbis0 libvorbis0-shlibs libmng2 libpng3 autoconf2.5 automake1.9 libtool wget curl boost1.33 pcre

Note: If you are using darwinports (instead of fink), build the packages you can't find that are listed in the fink command from source.

Install zlib

Download the zlib sources here. Unpack zlib.1.2.3.tar.gz to the Desktop, and issue the following commands: 

 $ cd Desktop/zlib-1.2.3
 $ make
 $ sudo make install prefix=/sw/


Install SVN

Download SVN with SSL support from Fink with the following command fink -y -v install svn-client

Setup Environment Variable for SVN

Because SVN will be installed into a directory that isn't in the PATH by default, there are two options. Please decide which you prefer using.

Option #1 - Storing the path permanently This option allows you to store the path once, and follow this guide "as-is". Create or modify your profile. Your profile stores commands that will be invoked every time you open a new terminal session. The single-user instructions allow you to modify only your terminal session. The multi-user instructions modify the terminal session of everyone when they open a terminal.

Bash Users Only - Please use either Single or Multiple User Instructions. This is the default shell for MacOSX. You can use other shells, but the instructions here are only for bash.

Single User Instructions: 

 $ nano ~/.profile

Multiple User Instructions: 

 $ nano /etc/profile

Paste the following lines into the file (for either Single or Multiple User Instructions). Note: To exit nano, press Ctrl-X, then y to save the file, then enter to save to same location. The path is initially set to "/bin:/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/sbin" 

 $ export PATH=$PATH:/sw/bin/

For additional information please read the recommended bash tutorial.

Option #2 - Using a path to run the svn command If you prefer NOT to store environment variables permanently, you can run the svn command as follows: 

 $ /sw/bin/svn co ...

Simply add /sw/bin/ to the start of every svn command in this guide to find and run the command. Obtain Necessary Tools You should use the toolkit from nvidia (regardless of your graphics card) to get some of the fancy particle effects needed by Peragro's magic department. Download and install the NVIDIA toolkit from here. To install, just download the appropriate installer, and click on the installation application. Getting source files All the following commands are run as a normal user and Peragro will be built for that user only. Commands that you enter are in such boxes: command Everything else is the expected output on the console.

Choose a base directory for your installation. peragro will be installed into a subdirectory peragro in the base directory and it can be your home directory. I prefer to install in $HOME/development and so the guide will reflect this. First create your directory using sudo, then give yourself permission to write there. 

 $ sudo mkdir $HOME/development
 $ sudo chmod 777 $HOME/development

You should now change to your working directory. 

 $ cd $HOME/development

You can check out source files from SVN repositories or download a source snapshot. I'm not going to personally maintain any myself, but if you find one all you have to do is extract it into the directory you made earlier, and then skip the source download instructions below.

NOTE: When running SVN commands, if the download fails to complete. Try running the command again. Sometimes it takes 2 or 3 tries to get the entire download.

Get the Peragro sources 

 development $ svn co https://cyanox.nl/peragro/trunk peragro

Download Cal3D library sources. 

 development $ svn co -r 407 http://svn.gna.org/svn/cal3d/trunk/cal3d cal3d

Download the custom CEGUI library sources

Please note, this version of CEGUI is not from the CEGUI website.
The public version of CEGUI does not build properly on a mac.
This version of CEGUI is highly experimental and is being developed by Rolenun.

 development $ svn co https://cyanox.nl/peragro/branches/ceguibuildsystem ceguibuildsystem

Download CrystalSpace sources. 

 development $ svn co https://crystal.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/crystal/CS/trunk cs

Download CEL sources 

 development $ svn co https://crystal.svn.sourceforge.net/svnroot/cel/cel/trunk cel

Building CrystalSpace and Peragro

Using Environment Variable Loading or Profiling There are two options here, please read through and choose the one most appropriate for you.

Option #1 - Environment Variable Loading on Terminal Startup This option allows the environment variables to automatically load when you open a terminal.

Advantages: Allows you to run the program commands without worrying about loading the variables first. It will allow you to ignore using the "source profile" statements throughout this document.

Disadvantages: Allows one Peragro install per user (using the single user instructions). Allows one Peragro install per machine (using the multiple user instructions).

Simply edit the same file you did in "Setup Environment Variable for SVN" near the beginning of this document. For example: (bash users only) Single User Instructions: 

 development $ nano ~/.profile

Multiple User Instructions: 

 development $ nano /etc/profile

Option #2 - Profiling This option does not restrict the number of installs for Peragro with the profile based on number of users or by machine.

Advantages: The number of installs is not restricted by your profile (as it is in Option #1).

Disadvantages: You will need to source the profile before running the commands as will be shown later.

Simply create a new profile that sets all the necessary environment variables. For example: 

 development $ nano $HOME/development/profile

For Option #1 and Option #2: Now that you have the file open that you'd like to use: Copy and paste the following lines into the file then save it. 

 export CRYSTAL=$HOME/development/cs
 export CEL=$HOME/development/cel
 export CAL3D=$HOME/development/cal3d
 export CEGUI=$HOME/development/CEGUI-0.6.1

Note: To exit nano, press Ctrl-X, then y to save the file, then enter to save to same location.

If you chose option #2, then load the profile. You have to reload the profile every time you exit the console and start another one. 

 development $ source profile

Build Cal3D library 

 development $ cd $HOME/development/cal3d
 development/cal3d $ autoreconf --install --force
 development/cal3d $ ./configure --prefix=$CAL3D
 development/cal3d $ make
 development/cal3d $ make install

Install and Build CEGUI 

 development/cal3d $ cd ..
 development $ cp -rf ceguibuildsystem/* .
 development $ cd CEGUI-0.6.1
 development/CEGUI-0.6.1 $ ./autogen.sh
 development/CEGUI-0.6.1 $ ./configure --prefix=$CEGUI --without-xercesc --with-pcre=/sw
 development/CEGUI-0.6.1 $ jam -aq

Build CrystalSpace 

 development/CEGUI-0.6.1 $ cd ../cs
 development/cs $ ./bin/autogen.sh
 development/cs $ ./configure --without-python --without-java --with-cal3d=$CAL3D --with-cegui=$CEGUI
 development/cs $ jam libs plugins walktest cs-config


Build CEL 

 development/cs $ cd ../cel
 development/cel $ ./autogen.sh
 development/cel $ ./configure
 development/cel $ jam -aq libs plugins cel-config cel-config-1.9

Build Peragro 

 development/cel $ cd ../peragro
 development/peragro $ ./autogen.sh
 development/peragro $ ./configure --with-cal3d=$CAL3D --with-cegui=$CEGUI --with-boost=/sw

Patch bug #1

Edit the src/common/util/thread.h file.
Delete (or comment) the following lines from the top of the file: 

 #ifndef HAVE_PTHREAD_TIMEDJOIN_NP
 #define HAVE_PTHREAD_TIMEDJOIN_NP 1
 #endif

Patch bug #2

Edit the Jamconfig file and add the following lines below "CEGUI.AVAILABLE ?= yes ;"
Keep in mind that anytime you run ./configure, it will remove the changes in the Jamconfig file.
Replace $CEGUI with your $CEGUI directory in the lines below. 

 CEGUI.VERSION ?= 1.9 ;
 CEGUI.CFLAGS ?= -I/$CEGUI/BaseModules ;
 CEGUI.LFLAGS ?= -L/$CEGUI/./out/macosxx86/optimize/libs -lCEGUITGAImageCodec -lCEGUIExpatParser -lCEGUIBase -lCEGUIFalagardWRBase -lCEGUIOpenGLRenderer -lz -lpthread -lc -lm -ldl -lnsl -L/sw/lib -DCS_DEBUG ;
 CEGUI.INCLUDE_DIR ?= $CEGUI/BaseModules ;
 CEGUI.AVAILABLE_LIBS ?= CEGUIOpenGLRenderer CEGUIFalagardWRBase CEGUIBase CEGUIExpatParser CEGUITGAImageCodec ;

Patch bug #3 

 development/peragro $ cp -rf /sw/include/boost-1_33_1/boost .

Finish Building Peragro 

 development/peragro $ jam -aq

Running and testing with a local server.

In order to run the client simply make sure to load your profile variables in $HOME/development by running: 

 $ source $HOME/development/profile


Then cd into the peragro directory like so: 

 $ cd $HOME/development/peragro


Then to run the client run: 

development/peragro $ ./peragro


To test a local server you must launch one with: 

development/peragro $ ./peragro-server &


This will open the server in the background.
Run ./peragro to launch the client then select localhost in the server list.
